rules.description: The goal is to capture all of the opponent's pieces or block them so they cannot move.
The board is a 10x10 grid with 50 dark squares and 50 light squares. The game is played only on the dark squares.
Each player has 20 pieces, placed on the first 4 rows of dark squares on each player's side of the board.
Regular pieces (Men) move diagonally forward one square to an empty dark square. They cannot move backward unless capturing.
Kings move diagonally any number of squares (both forward and backward), provided the path is unobstructed.
If a player can capture an opponent's piece, they must do so. Captures are mandatory.
Captures are made by jumping over an opponent's piece to an empty square directly on the other side. Multiple captures are allowed in a single turn if possible.
Regular pieces can only capture forward diagonally. Kings can capture forward or backward diagonally.
Captured pieces are removed from the board after the capturing move is complete.
A regular piece is promoted to a King when it reaches the opponent's back row. Promotion happens at the end of the move.
A player wins if they capture all the opponent's pieces or if the opponent has no legal moves left.
The game ends in a draw if neither player can force a win, or if the same position repeats three times.
If multiple capturing options exist, players are free to choose any sequence of captures.
A King and a regular piece have equal priority in terms of mandatory capture.
If no pieces are captured in 25 consecutive moves by either player, the game is declared a draw.
Players should not distract or interfere with their opponent. Moves must be clear and deliberate.
